title: ‘Tokyo Vice’ Review: Nippon Noir
sub_head: HBO Max’s new series is based loosely on a Missouri-born man’s time as a crime reporter at a major Japanese newspaper.
body:
You can almost smell the aught-era nicotine in “Tokyo Vice,” an eight-part series “loosely” based on the Missouri-born Jake Adelstein’s life as a crime reporter for a major Japanese newspaper, and a treatment that renews one’s appreciation for the cigarette as a magic wand—a signifier of power, sex, distraction, attraction, disdain and something an actor can do with his hands. One can imagine director Michael Mann eager to get all film-noirish with the smokes, even during a multilingual, pandemic-era shoot of a story about crime in a country that doesn’t like to acknowledge it, and a culture rife with xenophobia and misogyny.
Indignation and fun, in other words. Mr. Mann (“Miami Vice” and “Heat” being the pertinent credits here) handled only episode 1—other participating directors include Josef Kubota Wladyka and the single-named Hikari. But he gives the project the shove-off it needs, sending Jake (Ansel Elgort) through a kind of origin-story montage that shows his intensive study of Japanese language, economics and meteorology; taking an aikido class; teaching an ESL class; and eventually entering a racist newsroom—where the pejorative “gaijin” (outsider) is heard often enough and Jake is caught completely off guard by the editorial policies at work. You don’t refer to a murder, for instance, as a murder—even if the victim is found with multiple stab wounds and a knife sticking out of his chest. Not until the police decide it’s a murder. And they might not.
